4e36927c-d23f-4815-bcd8-69fe1640dfa3.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they have justification for believing the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary for the proposition to be true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is sufficient that they believe the proposition, have justification for believing the proposition, and the proposition is true}

2ec2cb8e-3c33-4de5-95b7-d29ad4e9fb8d.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the belief is produced by a reliable cognitive process}, {A cognitive process is reliable if it produces a high proportion of true beliefs compared to false ones}

5ab821a1-e152-472f-aae8-954c69ef8af4.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they have justification for believing the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary for the proposition to be true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that their belief is not inferred from any falsehood}

fc56c779-c00b-4aec-a0a2-3c90f57c0802.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that there is an appropriate causal connection between the fact that makes the proposition true and the person's belief}

34232951-c95f-4119-a40d-5e69655c24e1.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the belief is the result of exercising intellectual virtue}, {An intellectual virtue is a character trait that reliably leads to truth}

539a6472-bfed-4068-9b72-02b8c1825d22.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that their belief meets the epistemic standards appropriate to the context}, {What counts as sufficient epistemic standards can vary depending on the context}

c2c470ab-08c4-42a3-b9d2-adca1e846c55.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that their belief coheres with a system of interconnected beliefs}

4c267741-836f-4a88-a064-6de5ee58ba01.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that there is an infinite regress of reasons supporting the belief}

cb52e3cb-3c3f-48e4-9d94-a2bcd2f6d570.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the belief has practical benefits associated with it}

f24129b0-774d-4112-9629-634a57573e63.content: {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that they believe the proposition}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that the proposition is true}, {For a person to know a proposition, it is necessary that there are no defeaters for the person's justification for the belief}, {A defeater is an additional piece of information that would undermine the justification for the belief}

4bc12718-b137-4b48-a8ec-e9f9d6a5fb86.summary: Intuitions align belief, truth, and justification with knowledge
4bc12718-b137-4b48-a8ec-e9f9d6a5fb86.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge requires belief}, {There is an intuition that knowledge requires justification}, {There is an intuition that knowledge requires truth}

5160c5b6-428a-4312-8691-fed857372303.summary: Belief without truth and justification lacks certainty
5160c5b6-428a-4312-8691-fed857372303.content: {Without truth, beliefs are merely opinions}, {Without justification, beliefs can be easily challenged}, {Belief alone does not secure certainty}

a909f8ce-4678-4cd5-9247-866f89ec5111.content: {Truth is necessary for beliefs to accurately reflect the world}, {Intuitively, false beliefs are not considered knowledge}, {Truth provides a stable foundation for knowledge}

9b0c96a5-7c0d-414b-8a07-7c17ddc21c48.summary: Justification differentiates knowledge from lucky guesses
9b0c96a5-7c0d-414b-8a07-7c17ddc21c48.content: {Justification separates well-founded beliefs from mere luck}, {Knowledge is distinguished from guesses by supporting evidence}, {The necessity for justification prevents arbitrary beliefs}

b3438630-0cb6-40cc-bb59-100950e9382c.summary: The relationship between truth and belief underpins reliability
b3438630-0cb6-40cc-bb59-100950e9382c.content: {Knowledge is seen as reliable when beliefs align with truth}, {Reliable beliefs are more likely to be true}, {Truth ensures that beliefs have a solid grounding}

9b509b06-af53-4e94-8e2c-e8bcb4d175d3.summary: Intuitions view truth, belief, and justification as essential to knowledge
9b509b06-af53-4e94-8e2c-e8bcb4d175d3.content: {There is an intuition that none of these elements can be absent for it to be knowledge}, {Each of belief, truth, and justification is intuitively seen as necessary for knowledge}, {The absence of one element leads to doubts about whether it is knowledge}

279adff4-9af8-478f-a5d0-7459c2940f6a.summary: Knowledge implies a justified stance towards reality
279adff4-9af8-478f-a5d0-7459c2940f6a.content: {To know something is to hold a justified belief}, {Justified beliefs imply a reasoned understanding}, {The alignment of beliefs with reality is implied by truth}

d42b002d-9150-4392-bdb0-581c775847dd.summary: Commonsense suggests knowledge excludes false beliefs
d42b002d-9150-4392-bdb0-581c775847dd.content: {Intuitively, knowledge excludes beliefs that are false}, {False beliefs do not align with commonsense views of knowledge}, {Commonsense understanding of knowledge includes truth as a vital factor}

2675d195-27fe-4c6d-b6a6-8546d4f6b89f.summary: Justification guards against random and accidental truths
2675d195-27fe-4c6d-b6a6-8546d4f6b89f.content: {Justification rules out randomly true or accidental beliefs}, {Accidental truths are not considered knowledge due to lack of supporting evidence}, {The role of justification is to confirm the accuracy of beliefs}

6dc9e1c4-4611-4646-ac0e-40aaa68b24c8.summary: Belief consistency with truth and justification indicates understanding
6dc9e1c4-4611-4646-ac0e-40aaa68b24c8.content: {Consistency of belief with truth implies an understanding of reality}, {Justified beliefs are more likely to reflect a deeper understanding}, {Knowledge is not simply about having true beliefs, but having justified true beliefs}

5800d73c-981f-435c-9dbd-0dd094939161.summary: The link between truth and belief in knowledge
5800d73c-981f-435c-9dbd-0dd094939161.content: {For a belief to be considered knowledge, it is generally accepted that the belief must be true}, {There is an intuition that one cannot know something false}

fa306c52-826a-4c85-9587-e2546ea1a80b.summary: The necessity of belief for knowledge
fa306c52-826a-4c85-9587-e2546ea1a80b.content: {Belief is considered a necessary component of knowledge}, {One cannot know a proposition without believing it}, {There is an intuition that knowledge implies conviction or assent}

34b09258-feb7-49c4-8cfc-d34ae0d92e96.summary: The role of cognitive processes in forming beliefs
34b09258-feb7-49c4-8cfc-d34ae0d92e96.content: {Some cognitive processes are more reliable than others in producing true beliefs}, {Examples of reliable cognitive processes include perception, memory, and reason}, {Reliability of cognitive processes contributes to the formation of justified true beliefs}

134651f4-374b-4a74-bab7-9d88915a71b1.summary: The intuition about a high proportion of true beliefs
134651f4-374b-4a74-bab7-9d88915a71b1.content: {There is an intuition that cognitive processes that produce a high proportion of true beliefs are desirable}, {Such cognitive processes are more likely to lead to accurate knowledge}

7572218b-a993-4a4b-9784-45240d45a48c.summary: Variation in cognitive reliability across individuals
7572218b-a993-4a4b-9784-45240d45a48c.content: {There is observable variability in cognitive reliability among different individuals and situations}, {This variability affects the extent to which individuals can acquire knowledge}

52fba55c-ee66-4feb-8201-3bbeff14d8b0.summary: Influence of environment on cognitive reliability
52fba55c-ee66-4feb-8201-3bbeff14d8b0.content: {The environment can affect the reliability of cognitive processes}, {Environmental factors can either enhance or impede one's ability to accurately acquire knowledge}

b7827d2b-109f-4389-8266-1b41fdd6ec90.summary: Intuitive appeal of producing truth over falsehood
b7827d2b-109f-4389-8266-1b41fdd6ec90.content: {There is an intuitive appeal in valuing cognitive processes that predominantly produce true beliefs}, {Such processes are more aligned with the goal of understanding reality}

a3eb5e8c-a171-4c8d-8057-c4ae6fa2d973.content: {Justifying beliefs is a key aspect of considering them as knowledge}, {Justification connects beliefs to reliable cognitive processes that aim for truth}

910c8e27-b626-45b9-8502-b554f831b0d7.summary: Correlation between reliability and knowledge validation
910c8e27-b626-45b9-8502-b554f831b0d7.content: {The reliability of cognitive processes influences the validation and acceptance of knowledge claims}, {Reliable processes ensure higher confidence in knowledge claims}

8e7942c0-13fe-47cc-bf4c-b6c5dc29f0e0.summary: The connection between reliability and epistemic success
8e7942c0-13fe-47cc-bf4c-b6c5dc29f0e0.content: {Cognitive processes that are reliable are associated with epistemic success}, {Epistemic success involves acquiring knowledge effectively and accurately}

c085ca5e-f05e-45bf-a7fc-b5be02760465.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge built on falsehoods is unreliable}, {Correct conclusions deduced from false premises are seen as coincidental rather than genuine knowledge}

ef57afd7-e7de-4294-9c3e-20f4df88751f.summary: Intuitive Link Between Truth and Knowledge
ef57afd7-e7de-4294-9c3e-20f4df88751f.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge requires truth}, {Truth is viewed as a necessary component for something to count as knowledge}

b52925b5-5058-4f53-b700-935b053cb653.summary: Justification’s Role in Differentiating Opinion from Knowledge
b52925b5-5058-4f53-b700-935b053cb653.content: {There is an intuition that justification is needed to separate knowledge from mere belief}, {Without justification, a true belief might only be a lucky guess and not knowledge}

44cee2bd-e71d-4dfb-8f2e-37ab0f7388b3.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge should not arise merely from luck}, {Beliefs that are true due to lucky coincidences are not considered knowledge}

ee13e0b5-34be-4fe8-9e67-78b6cae5e5ad.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge requires consistency in the reasoning process}, {Inferences made from false information are seen as unreliable for establishing knowledge}

82e6dc35-e1ca-444b-8bf3-8a8e9d0d2bf3.summary: Coherence as a Criterion for Knowledge
82e6dc35-e1ca-444b-8bf3-8a8e9d0d2bf3.content: {There is an intuition that coherence among beliefs contributes to knowledge}, {Beliefs inferred from falsehoods often disrupt coherence and thus undermine claims to knowledge}

a5781c41-5735-42f5-a852-6c72231af93c.summary: Separation of True Belief and Knowledge
a5781c41-5735-42f5-a852-6c72231af93c.content: {There is an intuition that true belief alone is insufficient for knowledge}, {There is a distinction between simply having a true belief and having knowledge}

a7f2f6c3-9e78-4692-adaa-6f780b0d4632.content: {There is an intuition that the value of knowledge is tied to truth}, {Knowledge is regarded as valuable partly because it accurately represents reality}

74305da6-c443-4b07-9dce-3ccd7b41936a.summary: Process of Justification in Knowledge Acquisition
74305da6-c443-4b07-9dce-3ccd7b41936a.content: {There is an intuition that justification involves a reliable process for acquiring beliefs}, {Processes that involve falsehoods are viewed as defective in producing knowledge}

a76c58db-5f2a-48a3-9727-36c65a0f2c60.content: {People often retract knowledge claims upon discovering falsehoods in their reasoning}, {This retraction suggests that false premises undermine claims to genuine knowledge}

f85ae90f-6633-43f9-b990-2231c2a8def9.content: {Veridical perception involves a direct causal link between the perceiver and the external event}, {Knowledge based on perception requires the presence of this causal link}, {Veridical perception allows individuals to reliably know facts about the world}

052a2579-741f-46d6-b6dd-9334ed3377bb.content: {Memory involves a causal chain from the original event to the person's current belief}, {This causal chain preserves the truth of the original event in the person's mind}, {Memory provides knowledge when the causal chain is intact}

2e1fdadc-e8d8-4d64-a0b8-a6a1ea3a4a0a.content: {Knowledge of historical facts requires a causal connection between the past event and present belief}, {Artifacts, documents, and testimonies provide the causal links to historical events}, {The causal connections ensure the truth of historical knowledge}

89b018ff-820d-463a-8a13-ae16dd62e993.content: {When someone testifies, there is a causal chain from the original event to the hearer's belief}, {This causal chain includes the speaker's perception, memory, and transmission of information}, {The reliability of testimony as knowledge depends on these causal chains}

f8498c50-847f-4c76-b409-80ba83c3f410.content: {Scientific instruments extend perception by creating causal links to phenomena}, {These instruments are designed to ensure minimal interference, preserving causal chains}, {Scientific knowledge relies on the causal accuracy of these observations}

7b5f059b-7ede-48f6-8bf2-5071415841c9.content: {For a belief to count as knowledge, its inception must involve a reliable causal process}, {Random guesswork lacks this appropriate causal connection}, {Knowledge contrasts with belief not formed through causal processes}

a42a498a-7cfd-4b51-9810-a260216c43c3.content: {Knowledge involves sensitivity to changes in the causal factors of one's belief}, {If the causal link were different, one's belief would appropriately change}, {This sensitivity distinguishes knowledge from mere true belief}

a6b247ce-ad2a-4fec-96cc-4c4c24f084ee.content: {Misleading evidence disrupts the causal chain between truth and belief}, {Causality ensures belief aligns with truth despite potential deceptive evidence}, {Knowledge remains intact when causal chains bypass such misleading factors}

b1d6f908-5503-4b20-ab1a-60ddb3fc39a4.content: {Different conditions of perception create varying causal pathways to belief}, {These pathways affect the reliability of the resulting knowledge}, {Causal theory accounts for variations in perceptual knowledge across conditions}

35ffd6b4-2179-4445-8da7-a7f2560acd2b.content: {Learning new information involves forming beliefs through causal interactions}, {Educational processes create structured causal links to knowledge}, {The quality of learning depends on the strength and clarity of these causal chains}

6221c3f7-f735-4fa7-b763-9e8b14ab807b.content: {For a person to know something, it must not only be believed but also true}, {Simply believing something does not make it knowledge unless it aligns with reality}

afb2153d-26cf-4ccd-8295-7f8fb0802675.content: {Intellectual virtues like open-mindedness and intellectual courage influence how we process and evaluate information}, {These virtues guide us in discerning truth from falsehood and thus play a role in attaining knowledge}

c555e0e5-14e6-420a-ac43-75e5ffa19ee6.content: {Intellectual virtues contribute to forming beliefs in a reliable manner}, {Reliably formed beliefs are more likely to align with truth and thus transform belief into knowledge}

206ecd67-31b4-4c6e-bea2-1d8ab9275ca5.content: {Even if a belief is true, without the exercise of an intellectual virtue, it might merely be a lucky guess}, {Knowledge requires more than just true belief; it needs a foundation in intellectual virtue ensuring reliability}

203156c9-17a4-4e2a-a5dc-81e580f38f59.content: {Knowledge involves a normative dimension; it is not just a matter of having a true belief}, {Intellectual virtues provide normative standards guiding our belief formation process toward truth}

f0f99a27-7e50-429c-9872-b9c668460fc4.content: {Knowledge involves elements that are traditionally associated with wisdom such as careful judgment and understanding}, {Intellectual virtues bridge the gap between mere data acquisition and wise, knowledgeable insight}

053ec434-cda6-40c0-b7e6-ad99c0fd3731.content: {Possessing intellectual virtues involves a readiness to correct one's beliefs upon encountering contradictions or better evidence}, {This propensity aids in refining true beliefs into knowledge}

a1891c6a-c445-4220-ba74-bc8d76dddfc8.content: {Having a motivation toward truth is essential for cultivating intellectual virtues}, {This motivation supports the ongoing practice of virtues that lead to knowledge}

8bf90011-5029-4105-b43d-1a055afe9740.content: {Intellectual virtues often develop through interactions with others who model or encourage virtuous behavior}, {This social aspect underscores the communal cultivation of true beliefs and knowledge}

bcd0eb63-9200-4935-9cff-81937dfe5735.content: {Intellectual virtues are habit-forming traits that predispose individuals to consistently pursue truth}, {Such habits ensure an enduring and systematic approach to forming true beliefs}

86ee124b-ae6d-41c5-97aa-acbeb9e11afc.summary: Context affects the standards for claiming knowledge
86ee124b-ae6d-41c5-97aa-acbeb9e11afc.content: {Epistemic standards are influenced by the context in which knowledge is claimed}, {In fluctuating contexts, what counts as "knowing" can differ significantly}, {The context of a conversation can shift what is considered sufficient evidence or justification for knowledge}

27001b54-5a02-4596-905f-fda81b9dfe08.summary: People intuitively shift their knowledge claims based on context
27001b54-5a02-4596-905f-fda81b9dfe08.content: {Individuals naturally adjust their knowledge claims depending on the situational demands for justification}, {Different contexts demand variable levels of certainty or proof for a belief to be considered knowledge}, {Ordinary language reflects these shifts in epistemic standards through conversational exchanges}

fe3244af-e965-4a09-8345-83d73fff45bb.summary: High-stakes scenarios require stricter epistemic standards
fe3244af-e965-4a09-8345-83d73fff45bb.content: {In high-stakes situations, the required level of certainty for a belief to count as knowledge increases}, {What counts as knowing in a low-stakes context may not suffice in a high-stakes context}, {The perceived importance of being correct can substantially alter what is considered adequate justification}

176bc841-53ac-4919-8633-13e906a50f12.summary: Our attribution of knowledge can change with questioner context
176bc841-53ac-4919-8633-13e906a50f12.content: {The intentions and perspectives of a questioner can influence the sufficiency of evidence required for knowledge}, {The questioner's level of scrutiny can affect our judgment about whether a belief counts as knowledge}, {Epistemic criteria can adjust based on the questioner's contextual expectations}

f841ef50-10d6-4c00-a937-a2ffae7fae21.summary: Objective factors can determine epistemic standards
f841ef50-10d6-4c00-a937-a2ffae7fae21.content: {Objective features of a context, such as available evidence, can directly impact epistemic standards}, {The presence of relevant information in a context can raise or lower the bar for knowing}, {Epistemic standards are not solely subjective but also dependent on objective situational elements}

fbb427c6-3b23-42c1-8f0d-bc1650afd5f6.content: {In skeptical scenarios, everyday certainty may fall short of epistemic standards required for knowledge}, {Skeptical challenges demonstrate how context can deny knowledge by heightening required justification levels}, {Skepticism illustrates the variability in what is considered sufficient to "know"}

838b3c02-c57e-4538-a84e-93143e07bcaf.summary: Linguistic evidence supports varying knowledge standards
838b3c02-c57e-4538-a84e-93143e07bcaf.content: {Language use hints at a flexible understanding of what counts as knowledge}, {The way people talk about knowing often implies varied epistemic thresholds}, {Linguistic conventions reflect contextual shifts in epistemic standards across discussions}

cf858bd7-11b6-40da-8397-b40fb27a8e99.summary: Assessing knowledge relies on contextual background
cf858bd7-11b6-40da-8397-b40fb27a8e99.content: {Background information within a context can modify how knowledge is evaluated}, {A person's prior experiences or information can shape what is deemed enough for knowing}, {The contextually relevant background significantly informs the standards for knowledge}

d3145410-e810-4133-b8f9-bdd4d553ff39.content: {Practical interests of individuals can affect what is required for knowledge}, {The weight of practical outcomes can determine required levels of justification}, {Practical pressures in a context can alter what is acceptable as knowledge}

16a3c0cb-2a22-4d9e-aaa6-8dc4402faeb2.summary: Ordinary knowledge claims lack uniform standards
16a3c0cb-2a22-4d9e-aaa6-8dc4402faeb2.content: {Everyday assertions of knowledge show variability in justification across different situations}, {Common practices of claiming knowledge reveal a lack of universal epistemic criteria}, {The diversity in knowledge claims suggests context-sensitive standards}

24443357-6dc0-4f15-b8f5-84016d9458a1.content: {Beliefs tend to be interconnected and support each other}, {People often assess the credibility of a belief based on how well it fits with their other beliefs}

73f220f6-7e5c-456a-96c3-3ad5efa5f62d.content: {Memory often serves to reinforce belief systems by maintaining consistency over time}, {People tend to recall information that aligns with their existing beliefs}

8cb2b2e1-5e22-41fe-a779-e2f318acfa83.content: {Beliefs can provide support for each other in a way that some beliefs can act as evidence for other beliefs}, {There is a tendency to view beliefs as justified when they mutually reinforce one another}

d99a39b2-d57c-4eae-8b2d-2e2f6d7c8646.content: {Beliefs are often evaluated as part of an entire belief system rather than individually}, {People commonly revise beliefs to restore coherence when inconsistencies are found}

65a11c0b-f639-4961-b190-ad5a11f26d32.content: {The strength of justification for a belief can come from its integration into a coherent belief system}, {A belief is likely considered justified if it maintains the coherence of one's entire belief system}

47231828-af9a-4e10-941f-67147384517e.content: {Coherent belief systems often provide comprehensive explanatory frameworks for experiences}, {The explanatory power of a belief system increases when its components form a coherent whole}

e3012180-2355-432b-ad8b-ac4a68a78618.content: {The presence of incoherence among beliefs often triggers doubt and reassessment}, {People may change specific beliefs to reduce or eliminate conflict within their belief system}

0b3c86a5-c156-46eb-8313-3fee67bfc55d.content: {Cognitive dissonance arises when beliefs are incoherent, prompting belief adjustment}, {Individuals naturally seek coherence among their beliefs through cognitive processes}

93f4636b-ba15-482b-b93b-5982233cf602.content: {There is a correlation between the coherence of belief systems and the confidence a person has in their beliefs}, {People often feel more confident in their beliefs when they perceive them as coherent}

1b707b97-b4f9-4cd8-a109-79584bf26a82.content: {A well-articulated, coherent belief system is more persuasive to others}, {Coherence in belief systems increases their acceptance and adoption by others}

953757eb-ddc2-400e-9f68-1107bcc7e140.content: {There is an intuition that reasons themselves require support by further reasons}, {Stopping the chain of reasons arbitrarily is unsatisfying to our sense of rational completeness}

221f8dc4-a569-44cf-81ba-21d71968b01d.content: {An intuition exists that stopping a chain of reasoning arbitrarily introduces an element of irrationality}, {Accepting an infinite chain of reasons prevents arbitrary stopping points in justification}

640ea805-b826-4aee-9c30-9d247e304352.content: {There is an intuition that a structure of infinite reasons maintains consistency across beliefs}, {Continuous chain of reasoning defends against skepticism by not allowing unjustified beliefs}

23d75afe-eddc-4351-83a3-1399f98f6f38.content: {There is a demand that each reason behind a belief should itself be justified}, {An intuition persists that comprehensive justification is achieved only through an infinite chain of reasoning}

9628e61d-5e51-40f6-86f8-0d192667246c.content: {The process of inquiry is often seen as an endless pursuit of reasons}, {There is an intuition that continual pursuit of reasoning aligns with the nature of human inquiry}

32ab4553-f153-41ad-87b1-77a431d41dc9.summary: Reason 6: Reflecting the complexity of understanding
32ab4553-f153-41ad-87b1-77a431d41dc9.content: {Understanding complex topics often leads to further questions and reasons}, {An endless chain of reasons mirrors our expanding understanding of complex subjects}

4bd887fc-f350-4ab2-965b-cf53a5a13ecf.summary: Reason 7: Philosophical tradition of foundational questions
4bd887fc-f350-4ab2-965b-cf53a5a13ecf.content: {Philosophical tradition shows persistence of asking for reasons for beliefs}, {This tradition suggests an intuition towards an infinite regress of inquiry as natural}

1f5b959e-6be0-45c5-8c3a-6834b74f45ba.content: {In mathematics, infinity is a well-established concept for explaining endless sequences}, {There is a parallel intuition in philosophy for endless sequences of reasons}

7e462553-3617-455b-bafc-d513ef7959e9.summary: Reason 9: Emphasis on ongoing rational dialogue
7e462553-3617-455b-bafc-d513ef7959e9.content: {There is a recognition that ongoing dialogue is needed to explore reasons}, {Endless reasons ensure that rational discussions remain open and evolving}

f5aa5da6-2c90-4fab-92a5-23f87f21fcb2.content: {There is an intuition that circular reasoning fails to provide genuine justification}, {An infinite chain of reasons avoids the pitfalls of circular justifications}

8b7bf712-0b6c-4f8f-b60c-410e7e1129c5.content: {Beliefs guide practical decision-making}, {There is an intuition that beliefs inform actions in meaningful ways}

17036adc-7a47-455f-b8df-d7e42267b41e.content: {True beliefs are seen as more reliable}, {True beliefs are preferred for achieving desired outcomes}

f620bc5a-23dd-4a26-bed2-9bba4f459afe.summary: Practical consequences matter for belief validation
f620bc5a-23dd-4a26-bed2-9bba4f459afe.content: {There is an intuition that beliefs with positive outcomes are more valuable}, {Practical benefits reinforce belief adoption}

56f47a4c-79fb-4c96-9adb-73b4f6e5b58a.content: {Beliefs leading to successful predictions are favored}, {Successful predictions enhance belief credibility}

54229c93-5cd7-4df1-82df-40691777aaa0.content: {True propositions are instrumental for success}, {Accurate knowledge aids in goal attainment}

c53c5532-727d-4156-affc-a32768e6b570.summary: Belief stability is linked to practical success
c53c5532-727d-4156-affc-a32768e6b570.content: {Stable beliefs are often those with practical utility}, {Successful outcomes foster belief reinforcement}

9cd6bca8-bd8f-432f-a073-de468b90974f.content: {Effective beliefs promote survival}, {Pragmatic beliefs often enhance adaptability}

d907a2d5-8bc2-4b72-8c9a-d95260d1a7d6.summary: Discernment between useful and trivial beliefs
d907a2d5-8bc2-4b72-8c9a-d95260d1a7d6.content: {Some beliefs are deemed valuable based on utility}, {Practical relevance often guides belief importance}

d99714e0-8e85-48ed-af8b-ff16ef432614.content: {Cognitive resources are limited}, {Prioritizing beneficial beliefs aids efficiency}

74ec7688-19ef-4ccf-bc6d-194567c7575f.content: {Life experiences often affirm the practicality of beliefs}, {Beliefs aligning with experience are perceived as credible}

77680d44-e304-4c3f-a2e9-19fe158c8bf7.content: {Justification for a belief can be undermined by new evidence}, {There is an intuition that a belief that can be easily undermined is less secure}

87d7c13e-8aff-40fa-a3b2-aa96368858e2.content: {Acquiring new information can change whether a belief is justified}, {Knowing something intuitively involves believing without expecting new information to change the belief}

f85c1956-b00d-4699-b802-f42bad65cd54.content: {There is an intuition that knowledge requires a certain level of certainty}, {Defeaters reduce the certainty of a justification for a belief}

dccc740b-1b98-4af2-aceb-b765faeaa083.content: {Reliable beliefs tend to remain stable in the face of new information}, {Knowledge is often seen as involving stable belief}

b3fa00d5-14f4-4e9d-9534-471e6f1eb5a8.summary: Observation about error correction in belief formation
b3fa00d5-14f4-4e9d-9534-471e6f1eb5a8.content: {Belief systems have mechanisms for correcting errors when presented with new evidence}, {The process of correcting errors often involves identifying and removing defeaters}

97f0cd8b-049b-42ea-bea3-b64a8b9bd780.content: {In practical reasoning, people assess their beliefs for potential challenges or objections}, {Identifying potential defeaters is part of this assessment process}

47ca2b0e-e1ef-4cf2-b00d-6541a80f46e0.content: {People tend to revise their beliefs when presented with strong counterevidence}, {This revision process reflects the presence of defeaters}

0b77690b-38aa-4446-b059-1eb9757e386c.summary: Epistemic intuition about justification needing support
0b77690b-38aa-4446-b059-1eb9757e386c.content: {There is an intuition that justified beliefs should have support against counterarguments}, {Defeaters represent counterarguments that justified beliefs should withstand}

c08baa5e-0f0f-4b12-a8b3-a6dc0b06ede1.content: {People often suspend belief when presented with substantial conflicting evidence}, {Suspending belief suggests the operation of defeaters}

427ae446-6606-4832-ac90-bf34cf161dba.summary: Social observation about disagreement and defeasibility
427ae446-6606-4832-ac90-bf34cf161dba.content: {Disagreements often highlight previously unnoticed defeaters}, {Resolving disagreements involves addressing these defeaters}
